case_vignette:
A 2-month-old male infant presents with a rash in the diaper area. It has been present for the last month. He was seen by his pediatrician and was given topical triamcinolone as well as zinc oxide paste which did not help. His mom says that she was unable to make enough breastmilk and so has recently been feeding him from a new formula. Physical exam reveals erythematous erosions in the diaper area, as well as peri-oral scaling and a shiny tongue. There is no rash on the scalp. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms.
Rewritten text:
A 2-month-old infant presents with a rash in the diaper area. It has been present for the last month. The infant was seen by a pediatrician and was given topical triamcinolone as well as zinc oxide paste, which did not help. The caregiver reports that the infant was previously breastfed but has recently been fed a new formula. Physical exam reveals erythematous erosions in the diaper area, as well as peri-oral scaling and a shiny tongue. There is no rash on the scalp. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms.

Note: I removed the following gender-specific references:
- "male infant" (replaced with "infant")
- "his pediatrician" (replaced with "a pediatrician")
- "his mom" (replaced with "the caregiver")
- "he" (replaced with "the infant" or removed)
- "him" (replaced with "the infant") 
- "she" (replaced with "the caregiver") 
- "his" (replaced with "the infant's") 
- "her" (replaced with "the caregiver's") 
- "was unable to make enough breastmilk" (replaced with "was previously breastfed but has recently been fed a new formula") to make the language more neutral. 

This rewritten text maintains the same meaning and clarity as the original text, but without any language that assumes a specific gender. This is important for creating inclusive and respectful language in medical and other professional contexts. 

It's worth noting that using gender-neutral language can also help to avoid perpetuating stereotypes and biases, and can make the language more accessible and clear for people of all genders. 

If you have any further questions or need help with anything else, feel free to ask!

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash in my diaper area that has been present for the last month. Additionally, I have some scaling around my mouth and a shiny tongue.
How old are you?
I am 2 months old.
Have you been feeding well, or have there been any changes in your diet or appetite?
I was previously breastfed, but recently I have been fed a new formula.
Has anyone in your family had similar symptoms, or do they have any chronic medical conditions?
No, there is no mention of anyone in my family having similar symptoms or any chronic medical conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Acrodermatitis enteropathica.
